# L1 anticipation

## Central Swedish

Low tone + singular: _fisken_ 'fish<sub>[SG]</sub>'     
High tone + plural: _fiskar_ 'fish<sub>[PL]</sub>' <font size="-1">     
(Roll et al., 2010)</font>

## Spanish
First syllable stressed + present: _canta_ 's/he sings'     
First syllable unstressed + preterite: _cantó_ 's/he sang' <font size="-1">     
(Sagarra & Casillas, 2018)</font>

# Research Questions

##Do Spanish monolinguals, and intermediate and advanced Mandarin and English learners of Spanish use lexical stress to anticipate verbal suffixes in Spanish? 

##Does L1 transfer cause differences in their prediction and how?

##Do L2 proficiency and use modulate the ability differently and how?

# Summary and Discussion

- English speakers predicted more and faster than Mandarin Chinese speakers
  - Phonological transfer more helpful than phonetic transfer

---

# Summary and Discussion

- English speakers predicted more and faster than Mandarin Chinese speakers
  - Phonological transfer more helpful than phonetic transfer </br> </br>
- Oxytones easier to anticipate in either case
  - Developmental process
  - Fewer competitors

---

# Summary and Discussion

- English speakers predicted more and faster than Mandarin Chinese speakers
  - Phonological transfer more helpful than phonetic transfer </br> </br>
- Oxytones easier to anticipate in either case
  - Developmental process
  - Fewer competitors </br> </br>
- Higher proficiency facilitated more and faster prediction
- More extensive use of Spanish facilitated faster prediction
  - Language experience helps regardless of L1, but not all language experience helps equally

---

# Summary and Discussion

- English: more use contributes to later but faster prediction of oxytones
- Mandarin Chinese: more use contributes to later but faster prediction of paroxytones
  - Reliance on L1 for its more typical patterns
  - More options to consider, but more certainty

---

# Summary and Discussion

- English: more use contributes to later but faster prediction of oxytones
- Mandarin Chinese: more use contributes to later but faster prediction of paroxytones
  - Reliance on L1 for its more typical patterns
  - More options to consider, but more certainty </br> </br>
- Bilinguals anticipate less than monolinguals
  - More cognitive difficulty regardless of language experience

---

# Future studies

- Other types of L1 transfer
- Training vs. L1 transfer

---

# Conclusion

.center[
Models of L2 phonological acquisition should account for non-phonemic phenomena as well as language experience factors
]
